newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Financial reshuffle rumours boost Brussels bourse.
newsitem.headline: Financial reshuffle rumours boost Brussels bourse.

text.p: Rampant rumours of a reshuffle in the Belgian financial sector boosted the Brussels bourse in morning trading on Friday, but traders noted that the relatively low volume of business was exaggerating the rise.
Trading in shares of financial holding companies Almanij, Cobepa, Gevaert, Ibel, Imperial Invest and Belvuco were all suspended pending announcements.
"There are strong rumours that Cobepa, through Ibel, will sell its stake in Gevaert to Almanij," one trader said. "That is really driving the market."
Almanij unit Kredietbank was a major beneficiary of the rumours, surging 4.7 percent to 14,400 francs.
"Kredietbank would gain from such a deal," one trader said.
Another major rumour driving the market was that insurer Royale Belge was about to be sold.
"There is widespread talk that a deal to sell Royale Belge to either Winterthur of Switzerland or the Dutch ING is close to completion," one trader said.
Royale Belge, controlled by AXA/UAP group and Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, was up 4.2 percent at 10,100 francs.
There was no immediate confirmation of the rumours.
Nevertheless Groupe Bruxelles Lambert gained 0.9 percent to 5,600 francs.
Elsewhere the market was relatively calm but enjoying the ride skywards.
The Bel-20 index of blue chip shares was up 13.18 points or 0.59 percent at 2,258.72 at 0900 GMT, with 10 gainers, five unchanged and five losers.
A total of 700 million francs of Belgian shares changed hands.
